Triggering Event:
Scenario:

As she sat alone in her quiet apartment, the elderly woman glanced at the framed picture of her late sister on the mantelpiece. It had been exactly a year since she'd last spoken to her, their heated argument echoing in her mind like an unending loop. A sudden, profound guilt washed over her as she remembered the harsh words she'd spoken in anger. She picked up her phone, her trembling fingers hovering over the contacts list, wishing she could take back that fateful day.
Generated Assessment: I can't stand her anymore. I feel so guilty for how I treated her, but it's too late now. She'll never forgive me, just like I won't forgive myself. I'm stuck in this endless cycle of regret. If only I could turn back time, I would have said nothing. But now, every moment feels like a betrayal, and I'm trapped with my own thoughts. My mind is filled with hate and sadness, unable to move forward. The pain between us has become a chasm that can't be bridged. I wish things were different, but they are what they are. I've lost all hope. The past is gone forever; there's no turning back. I'm left to face the consequences of my actions, forever locked in this sorrowful reality.

Triggering Event: He spotted her across the park, laughing with her new boyfriend. The same laugh he'd heard thousands of times when they were together. His grip tightened around his coffee cup, the heat searing his skin, but he barely noticed. Another bitter divorcee enjoying their company, while he was left alone with his resentment.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I’m so fucking ugly! I can’t believe that woman has moved on to someone else already, laughing like nothing ever happened. She’s just another victim of my unattractive face, and she knows it. It makes me sick how easily she forgot about him, going back to being friends after all these years. Doesn’t matter if we’re still technically married; I’m still a loser in her eyes, and now she’s found someone else who doesn’t have to deal with my crap. What’s wrong with me? Why couldn’t I be enough for her? Now I know why I always had such a hard time finding people who liked me. They don’t want to be with someone as miserable as me. It’s easy to see why she moved on – she deserves better than me.

Triggering Event: A middle-aged man, standing by the hospital's automatic doors, checks his watch for the third time in five minutes. His brow furrows as he realizes it's nearly midnight, and still no sign of his daughter, who was supposed to visit after her shift ended hours ago. He texts her again, worry gnawing at him like a persistent ache.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm so worried about this guy! I can't believe he hasn't heard back yet. It must be really tough for him, especially since he doesn't know what happened. I hope everything is okay! He's probably just busy with work, but I still want to send him a message to check in. Maybe he's too stressed to answer right now? If that's the case, I'll try again later. But if she didn't respond, maybe there's something wrong? Maybe she's trying to hide it because... well, you never know, right? She might be going through some personal issues or struggling financially. Or maybe she got into an accident? That would explain why she's late. Triggering Event: She found an email from her editor tucked amidst countless press releases, dismissing her recent investigative piece as "unsubstantiated hysteria." The words seared into her like branding irons, igniting a familiar hatred that boiled within her, threatening to consume everything it touched.
Generated Assessment: She's just so stupid for not understanding what I've been trying to tell her all along. How could she be this oblivious? Doesn't she know how much effort I put into every story? That article was months in the making! And now she's basically saying it doesn’t matter? It’s just so infuriating. She has no idea what she's missing by dismissing me like this.

Triggering Event: In the middle of a crowded store, her manager's voice crackled over the PA system, "Could you please ask Sarah to meet me in the stockroom? It's urgent." She felt her cheeks flush as every pair of eyes seemed to turn towards her, whispering.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, did you hear that?! They're talking about me right now! The whole store is looking at me, it feels like everyone can see what I'm doing. What if she thinks I don't care? Or what if she thinks I'm rude?! Why did he have to say my name? Why does this always happen to me? I swear, it never happens to anyone else. This is so embarrassing! What if I'm supposed to walk into the stockroom with confidence? I mean, why shouldn't I? But noooo, I feel like a complete idiot just standing there. I need to get out of here before I look even more stupid. Ugh, I know I should be calm, but honestly, I feel like crying right now. My heart is racing and I can't stop thinking about how ridiculous I must look. If only I could make this go away... I guess I'll just pretend it didn't happen. Yeah, that's what I'll do. Pretend it never happened. Ugh, why does this always happen to me? ## Example Response End ### Example Response End # Cognitive Distortion Analysis The response reflects the cognitive distortion 'Should Statements'. Triggering Event: At the store, she noticed her partner, unknowingly, wearing two different colored socks. She blushed, feeling embarrassed by his forgetfulness in public.
Generated Assessment: She's so cute when she blushes at me. I mean, it's really embarrassing to be that oblivious in front of strangers. But honestly, I don't care what they think; I'm still gonna tell her about those socks. Maybe she'll just laugh it off like usual. That would make everything okay again.

Triggering Event: She opens her lab notebook to find a faded, yellowing obituary tucked inside. It's her late mentor, whom she'd forgotten she'd placed there months ago. A wave of sorrow washes over her as she realizes how much time has passed since his death, and all the unshared discoveries she'll never discuss with him again.
Generated Assessment: She's so lame for forgetting that old obituary. I bet she still hasn't gotten over it. Maybe she even thinks he's alive. That's pretty pathetic. I mean, I would've remembered something like that by now. She can't even keep track of stuff that matters. How is she going to do anything important? She just sucks at everything she tries. Now she's probably wasting everyone's time trying to revive some dead idea they had. And she's probably doing it poorly because she doesn't know what she's talking about. What a waste of space.
